questions.question: A white solid dissolves in water. With NaOH, white precipitate soluble in excess. With HCl, effervescence. What ions present?
questions.explanation: Zn²⁺ gives white ppt with NaOH soluble in excess. CO₃²⁻ gives effervescence with acid. Could be zinc carbonate.

questions.question: A colourless solution gives white precipitate with NaOH insoluble in excess. With NH₃, no precipitate. With AgNO₃, white precipitate soluble in NH₃. Identify.
questions.explanation: White ppt with NaOH insoluble: Ca²⁺ or Mg²⁺. No ppt with NH₃ suggests Ca²⁺. White ppt with AgNO₃ soluble in NH₃ suggests Cl⁻.

questions.question: A green solution gives green precipitate with NaOH turning brown. With BaCl₂, white precipitate insoluble in acid. Identify.
questions.explanation: Green solution and green ppt turning brown suggests Fe²⁺ oxidation. White ppt with BaCl₂ insoluble in acid suggests SO₄²⁻. Could be FeSO₄.

questions.question: Which pair of ions would both give white precipitates with NaOH?
questions.explanation: Both Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ give white precipitates with NaOH: Ca(OH)₂ and Mg(OH)₂ respectively.

questions.question: Which ions would NOT give any precipitate with NaOH?
questions.explanation: NH₄⁺ gives ammonia gas, not precipitate. Na⁺ gives no reaction with NaOH.

questions.question: A solution gives red-brown precipitate with NaOH. With HCl, no effervescence. With AgNO₃, white precipitate. Identify possible ions.
questions.explanation: Red-brown precipitate suggests Fe³⁺. No effervescence with HCl excludes CO₃²⁻. White ppt with AgNO₃ suggests Cl⁻. Could be FeCl₃.

questions.question: An unknown gives: With BaCl₂ → white ppt soluble in acid. With AgNO₃ → yellow ppt. With NaOH → no change. Identify anions.
questions.explanation: White ppt with BaCl₂ soluble in acid: SO₃²⁻ (BaSO₃). Yellow ppt with AgNO₃: I⁻ (AgI).

questions.question: A solution gives white precipitate with NaOH that dissolves in excess. With NH₃, white precipitate insoluble in excess. Identify cation.
questions.explanation: Al³⁺ gives white Al(OH)₃ soluble in excess NaOH but insoluble in excess NH₃.
